results.title: Conversations with a dead poet: Alan Wearne recalls John Forbes [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Geoff Burton, John Izzard, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Seedwillow
results.brief_description: Alan Wearne, poet and tutor hosts this documentary about his friend and colleague John Forbes (1950-98), one of Australia’s most prominent modern poets with his distinctly gritty writing about urban Melbourne and Sydney. Drawing on extracts from several of Forbes’ poems, and discussions with friends and devotees of his writing, the following works are explored in detail: “Tropical skiing”; “On the beach”; “Stalin’s holidays”; “The Stunned mullet”; “Damaged glamour”.
results.title_for_label: Conversations with a dead poet: Alan Wearne recalls John Forbes [Widescreen]

results.title: Contradictions
results.creator_credit: David Knaus, Janet Bell, Film Australia and Knaus Films
results.brief_description: This film by award-winning cinematographer David Knaus is a very powerful story about the contradictory perceptions and roles of Americans in relation to the war in Nicaragua. It begins with the Congressional Hearings of the infamous Lt. Colonel “Ollie” North. It includes interviews with Comandante Tomas Borge, Nicaragua’s Minister for the Interior and comments from an ex-CIA agent and contra army commanders. Yet the core of “Contradictions” is the story of the ordinary citizens themselves. Nicaraguans wearied by the interference; U.S. citizens who feel they must take responsibility for the “War Crimes” of their administration. This is an important film and should be seen by anyone interested in Central America and recent American history and foreign policy. It won Best Foreign Film at the 1988 Cuban Film Festival.

results.title: Continuum
results.creator_credit: Ian Ball, Derek Lamb, Sidney Goldsmith and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film is an excellent introduction to Einstein’s Special Theory of Relativity, one aspect of his General Theory of Relativity. Dr. Banesh Hoffman, a friend, collaborator, and biographer of Einstein, explains the theory’s development. Realistic animation illustrates the principles involved, facilitating their comprehension. Dr. Hoffman’s recollections of Einstein’s personal philosophy of life add a human dimension to an otherwise scientific exposition.

results.title: Contemporary trends
results.creator_credit: Eve Cotton and Center for Humanities
results.brief_description: This video describes the American art scene in the 1940’s when painters in New York developed Abstract Expressionism. Among the artists represented are Jackson Pollock, Willem de Kooning, Franz Kline, Adolph Gottlieb and Mark Rothko. Also examines the Minimal, Pop, Conceptual and Photorealist movements.

results.title: Contemporary case studies
results.creator_credit: Janet Merewether and Go Girl Productions
results.brief_description: A wry comment on the state of heterosexual romance and sex in the 21st century from a female perspective, this short experimental film consists of nine case studies ‘as witnessed from life’. Through the use of split-screens Merewether juxtaposes text and images to comment on the all-too-familiar scenarios, conversations and discussions that constitute modern day (mis)understandings about what women do and don’t want. Photography by Jackie Farkas.

results.title: Consuming passions
results.brief_description: As shown on ABC TV, Ian Parmenter shows how quick and easy it is to prepare dishes, using simple recipes and good ingredients. Ian’s methods are elementary, requiring few skills and employing basic kitchen implements. Food preparation techniques are explained and advice provided. The recipes include bread, honey prawns, mayonnaise, pasta, rice dishes, stir fry and various sweet dishes. Produced with the assistance of the National Heart Foundation.

results.title: Conspiracy of silence
results.creator_credit: Niev Ghira, Vladimir Valenta and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A dramatic film about generational differences that almost split a family apart. Anna, fifteen, dates Bill. Her parents don’t trust her. Jack, her brother, committed suicide a year ago. Her parents disguised it as a car accident. Tension builds between Anna and her parents until she attempts suicide. The magnitude of their problems prompts a family reconciliation. Dramatic, realistic, fast-moving, this film sounds an alarm on the subject of teenage suicide. Cast includes Murray Berg, Warren W. Sulatychy, Judy Wood, Robert Galbraith, Tommy Banks, Jana Lapel Millman.

results.title: Constructing Australia
results.creator_credit: Alex West, Film Australia, Piper Films, Prospero Productions and Real Pictures
results.brief_description: The Sydney Harbour Bridge, the Kalgoorlie Pipeline and the Overland Telegraph were amongst Australia’s most significant civil engineering projects. “Constructing Australia” is a series of three films - “The Bridge”, “Pipe Dreams” and “A Wire Through the Heart” - that tells the story behind these landmarks in the construction of white Australian society. Combining dramatic re-enactments with archival footage, documentary sources, and interviews, the three films deal not only with the practical challenges and problems that faced each of the projects, but also reveal the personal triumphs and tragedies, the political intrigues, the human dramas and the social contexts behind these pioneering events.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alex West, Film Australia, Piper Films, Prospero Productions and Real Pictures

results.title: Consenting adult
results.creator_credit: Gilbert Cates, David Lawrence, Ray Aghayan and Starger Company
results.brief_description: Set in the pre-AIDS era, this made for television film focuses on the story of a family torn apart when their son announces he is a “homosexual”. All American college student Jeff Lynd (Barry Tubb) is the only son of an ill and emotionally inept father (Martin Sheen) and well intentioned home-maker mother (Marlo Thomas). Fearing his father’s reaction, Jeff comes out to his mother and asks her for help, she misinterprets this as believing he wants to be “cured” and sends her son to a psychiatrist. When her husband finds out Jeff is gay and does not want to be “cured”, he disowns him, fracturing the family further. Jeff finds a sympathetic ear with his married sister Margie (Talia Balsam), but remains estranged from his father until death finally brings them tenuously and posthumously together. Jeff comes out in the first fifteen minutes of the film, consequently the remainder of the film is about how the family react to the news; shock, disbelief, anger and confused acceptance. The representation of Jeff’s sexual awakening is chastely portrayed off screen; presumably it’s the content matter that has prescribed the M rating. Based on the novel by Laura Z. Hobson.
